p.span: Areas of the Event Horizon and Stationary Limit Surface for a Kerr Black Hole
C. A. Pickett and J. D. ZundaùëéFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}
Departments of Mathematical Sciences and Physics,
New Mexico State University, Las Cruces, New Mexico, 88003

div.p: The notions of an event horizon, (EH), and stationary limit surface, (SLS), are important concepts in black hole physics. The former requires no comment, while the latter is less well-known. The SLS geometrically bounds a region outside the EH known as an ergosphere. Inside the ergosphere a test particle cannot travel along the orbit of a timelike Killing vector and remain at rest11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}, and the red shift is infinite on the SLS22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}.

While surface area of an EH has been related to the entropy of a black hole33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3}, that of the SLS has not been given a physical interpretation. In this note our approximate evaluation of the area of a SLS suggests a reinterpretation of the area of an EH.

Employing the original form of the uncharged Kerr solution4,545FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 PUNCT:, NUMBER:5 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{4,5}, (KS), expressed in spherical polar coordinates (Œ∏,œï)ùúÉitalic-œïOPEN:( italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-phi CLOSE:)(\theta,\phi), the angular part d‚Å¢œâ2ùëësuperscriptùúî2italic-d italic-omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endd\omega^{2} of the line element d‚Å¢s2ùëësuperscriptùë†2italic-d italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endds^{2} is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-d italic-omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-theta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta OPEN:[ italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m italic-r ARG:end ARG:start italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta CLOSE:] italic-d italic-phi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
d\omega^{2}=\rho^{2}d\theta^{2}+\sin^{2}\theta\left[r^{2}+a^{2}+\frac{2mr}{% \rho^{2}}\ a^{2}\sin^{2}\theta\right]d\phi^{2}

div.p: where

semantics.annotation: italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta

div.p: with 0<Œ∏<œÄ,‚ÄÖ0‚â§œï‚â§2‚Å¢œÄformulae-sequence0ùúÉùúã‚ÄÖ0italic-œï2ùúãNUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than italic-theta RELOP:less-than italic-pi PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-phi RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi0<\theta<\pi,\ 0\leq\phi\leq 2\pi. This expression employs geometric, or relativistic, units in which the speed of light and the Newtonian gravitational constant are unity. Quantity aùëéitalic-aa is then the angular momentum JùêΩitalic-JJ per unit mass of a spinning particle of mass mùëöitalic-mm. Note that a‚â†0ùëé0italic-a RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0a\neq 0 for the KS, and when a=0ùëé0italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:0a=0 the KS reduces to the Schwarzschild solution, (SS).
Rewriting (1) as

semantics.annotation: italic-d italic-omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
d\omega^{2}=\gamma_{AB}\ dx^{A}dx^{B}

div.p: where xA=(Œ∏,œï),A=2,3formulae-sequencesuperscriptùë•ùê¥ùúÉitalic-œïùê¥23italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-phi CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-A RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3x^{A}=(\theta,\phi),\ A=2,3, the area ùêÄùêÄbold-A{\bf A} of the corresponding 2-dimensional (angular) surface is given by

semantics.annotation: bold-A RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start LIMITOP:determinant italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-d italic-theta italic-d italic-phi PERIOD:.
{\bf A}=\int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_{0}^{\pi}\sqrt{\det\gamma_{AB}}\ d\theta d\phi.

div.p: Inspection of det‚Å°Œ≥A‚Å¢Bsubscriptùõæùê¥ùêµLIMITOP:determinant italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\det\gamma_{AB} shows that it is independent of œïitalic-œïitalic-phi\phi, so consequently (4) reduces to

semantics.annotation: bold-A RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start LIMITOP:determinant italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-d italic-theta PERIOD:.
{\bf A}=2\pi\int_{0}^{\pi}\sqrt{\det\gamma_{AB}}\ d\theta.

p.span: III. SURFACE AREAS OF THE EH AND SLS

div.p: By definition, for an EH

semantics.annotation: italic-r RELOP:equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-m ADDOP:plus italic-square-root ARG:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end

div.p: and for a SLS

semantics.annotation: italic-r RELOP:equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-m ADDOP:plus italic-square-root ARG:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta ARG:end
r=r_{SLS}=m+\sqrt{m^{2}-a^{2}\cos^{2}\theta}

div.p: Then, upon using these values of rùëüitalic-rr in (5), one obtains expressions for the respective surface areas ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH} and ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}. ¬†Of course, for the SS, since a=0ùëé0italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:0a=0 the EH and the SLS coincide.
Evaluation of (5) for the EH is elementary, and one immediately obtains

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:8 italic-pi italic-m OPEN:( italic-m ADDOP:plus italic-square-root ARG:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.
{\bf A}_{EH}=8\pi m\left(m+\sqrt{m^{2}-a^{2}}\right).

div.p: However, the evaluation of (5) for the SLS is non-trivial, and involves the integral

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-m INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-m italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta ARG:end MULOP:cdot TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta italic-d italic-theta PERIOD:.
{\bf A}_{SLS}=4\pi m\int_{0}^{\pi}r_{SLS}\sqrt{1+\frac{a^{2}}{mr_{SLS}}\sin^{2% }\theta}\cdot\sin\theta\ d\theta.

div.p: The difficulty calculating this is obvious since rS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùëüùëÜùêøùëÜitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{SLS} involves Œ∏ùúÉitalic-theta\theta, and appears twice in the integrand!

To the best of our knowledge, no one has succeeded in evaluating the integral (9) in closed form. It is perhaps noteworthy that in his treatise55FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{5} Chandrasekhar calculated ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH} and gave the result (8), but made no comment about the evaluation of (9). Indeed, he did not even cite an approximate expression for ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}.

p.span: IV. AN APPROXIMATE EVALUATION OF AS‚Å¢L‚Å¢Ssubscriptùê¥ùëÜùêøùëÜitalic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{SLS}

div.p: Since the expression (9) seems to be intractable it is natural to seek an approximate determination of ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}.
Fortunately, both the uncharged KS and the ‚ÄòNo Hair‚Äô theorem require that

semantics.annotation: italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:,

div.p: and this permits us to obtain an approximate expression for ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}. The elementary inequality, which is easily proven,

semantics.annotation: italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1 ARROW:Rightarrow italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1 PUNCT:,
a^{2}/m^{2}\ll 1\Rightarrow a^{2}/mr_{SLS}\ll 1,

div.p: then permits us to do a binomial expansion

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-X CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus-or-minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-X PUNCT:,
(1\pm X)^{1/2}\simeq 1\pm\frac{1}{2}X,

div.p: with X‚â™1much-less-thanùëã1italic-X RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1X\ll 1, for the radical in rS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùëüùëÜùêøùëÜitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{SLS}.

For ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS} this expansion must be used twice. First, expansion of the radical in the integrand yields

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-m INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta CLOSE:) TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta italic-d italic-theta
{\bf A}_{SLS}\simeq 4\pi m\int_{0}^{\pi}r_{SLS}\left(1+\frac{a^{2}}{2mr_{SLS}}% \sin^{2}\theta\right)\sin\theta\ d\theta

div.p: which we split into two integrals:

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-m OPEN:{ INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta italic-d italic-theta ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m ARG:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta italic-d italic-theta CLOSE:} PERIOD:.
{\bf A}_{SLS}\simeq 4\pi m\left\{\int_{0}^{\pi}r_{SLS}\sin\theta\ d\theta+% \frac{a^{2}}{2m}\int_{0}^{\pi}\sin^{3}\theta\ d\theta\right\}.

div.p: The first integrand in (14) requires a second expansion,

semantics.annotation: ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta italic-d italic-theta CELL:end CELL:start RELOP:similar-to-or-equals CELL:end CELL:start italic-m INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta italic-d italic-theta CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start CELL:end CELL:start RELOP:similar-to-or-equals CELL:end CELL:start italic-m INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta CLOSE:) TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta italic-d italic-theta CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start CELL:end CELL:start RELOP:equals CELL:end CELL:start italic-m OPEN:( NUMBER:4 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:; CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

\normalsize{\begin{array}[]{lll}\int_{0}^{\pi}r_{SLS}\sin\theta\ d\theta&% \simeq&m\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(1-\frac{a^{2}}{m^{2}}\cos^{2}\theta\right)^{1/2}% \sin\theta\ d\theta\\ &\simeq&m\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(2-\frac{a^{2}}{2m^{2}}\cos^{2}\theta\right)\sin% \theta\ d\theta\\ &=&m\left(4-\frac{1}{3}\ \frac{a^{2}}{m^{2}}\right);\end{array}}

div.p: while the second integral in (14) is elementary

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-theta italic-d italic-theta RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: Adding these two expressions and multiplying by 4‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢m4ùúãùëöNUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-m4\pi m, we obtain

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:16 italic-pi italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-pi ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
{\bf A}_{SLS}\simeq 16\pi m^{2}+\frac{4\pi}{3}a^{2}

div.p: which is our approximate evaluation of ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}.

p.span: V. A GEOMETRIC REINTERPRETATION OF AE‚Å¢Hsubscriptùê¥ùê∏ùêªitalic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{EH} AND AS‚Å¢L‚Å¢Ssubscriptùê¥ùëÜùêøùëÜitalic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{SLS}

div.p: Although we have the exact value of ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH} exhibited in (8), since we have only an approximate value for ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}, it seems natural to consider what our approximation procedure gives for ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH}. This is easy, and by using (12) in (8) we obtain

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:16 italic-pi italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
{\bf A}_{EH}\simeq 16\pi m^{2}-4\pi a^{2}

div.p: which invites a comparison with (15). By recalling that the usual Euclidean surface area of a sphere is

semantics.annotation: NUMBER:4 italic-pi OPEN:( italic-r italic-a italic-d italic-i italic-u italic-s CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,
4\pi(radius)^{2},

div.p: we observe that

semantics.annotation: NUMBER:16 italic-pi italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-m CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where rS=2‚Å¢msubscriptùëüùëÜ2ùëöitalic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-mr_{S}=2m is the Schwarzschild radius.

This suggests calling the expression in (17), which is the common value of ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH} and ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS} for the SS, the Schwarzschild area

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: Of course, for the KS the expressions (15) and (16) are more complicated. However, both the second terms on the right hand sides of these expressions involve the ubiquitous factor of 4‚Å¢œÄ4ùúãNUMBER:4 italic-pi4\pi. This suggests introducing the notion of an angular momentum sphere having a‚â†0ùëé0italic-a RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:0a\neq 0 as a radius, since dimensionally in geometrized units aùëéitalic-aa is a length. Such a sphere has the Euclidean surface area

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: and hence we can rewrite (16) and (15) as

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
\displaystyle{\bf A}_{EH}\simeq{\bf A}_{S}-{\bf A}_{J}

bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.
\displaystyle{\bf A}_{SLS}\simeq{\bf A}_{S}+\frac{1}{3}{\bf A}_{J}.

div.p: These show, as is to be expected, that ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢S>ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}>{\bf A}_{EH} with ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢S=ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS}={\bf A}_{EH} only for the SS. The values of ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH} and ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS} given in (20) are surprisingly close in contrast to the usual pictorial illustrations of the ergosphere given in the literature.

p.span: VI. NUMERICAL EVALUATION OF AE‚Å¢Hsubscriptùê¥ùê∏ùêªitalic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{EH} AND AS‚Å¢L‚Å¢Ssubscriptùê¥ùëÜùêøùëÜitalic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{SLS}

div.p: Since the approximate values of ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH} and ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS} in (20) are curiously close and tantalizingly simple, one wonders whether this is accidental, or quite sensible. ¬†While our use of the binomial expansion (12) seems sensible, are we justified in omitting the higher order terms?

To answer this question we have done a numerical computation of ùêÄE‚Å¢HsubscriptùêÄùê∏ùêªbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{EH} and ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS} by using Mathcad66FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{6}. This computes definite integrals by using a Romberg algorithm which accelerates the convergence of a sequence of simple trapezoidal / midpoint approximations of the value of the integral by extrapolating both the sequence of estimates and the widths of the subintervals. Since our goal is to check the accuracy of the expressions given in (20), we will use the values of aùëéitalic-aa and mùëöitalic-mm given by Shapiro and Teukolsky77FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{7}, and let Mathcad choose the method of evaluation with an automatic default setting of 0.001.

Then in geometric units: m=1.478√ó105‚Å¢c‚Å¢m,J=4.034√ó109‚Å¢c‚Å¢m2formulae-sequenceùëö1.478superscript105ùëêùëöùêΩ4.034superscript109ùëêsuperscriptùëö2italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.478 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m PUNCT:, italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.034 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endm=1.478\times 10^{5}cm,J=4.034\times 10^{9}cm^{2} so that a=2.73√ó104‚Å¢c‚Å¢mùëé2.73superscript104ùëêùëöitalic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.73 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-ma=2.73\times 10^{4}cm, and

semantics.annotation: italic-a MULOP:divide italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.185 PERIOD:.

div.p: Upon direct calculation (15) gives

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.101 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: while Mathcad‚Äôs evaluation is

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.094 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: Upon taking the latter to be ‚Äòexact‚Äô this yields an error of 5.797√ó10-3‚Å¢c‚Å¢m25.797superscript103ùëêsuperscriptùëö2NUMBER:5.797 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end5.797\times 10^{-3}cm^{2}, i.e. 0.58%.
Likewise, upon direct evaluation (16) gives

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.089 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: while evalution of the exact expression (8) yields

semantics.annotation: bold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-E italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.089 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: and the error between these is 8.128√ó107‚Å¢c‚Å¢m28.128superscript107ùëêsuperscriptùëö2NUMBER:8.128 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end8.128\times 10^{7}cm^{2}, i.e. 0.008%.

This numerical comparison gives us confidence in the accuracy of the approximate value of ùêÄS‚Å¢L‚Å¢SsubscriptùêÄùëÜùêøùëÜbold-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-L italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf A}_{SLS} displayed in equation (15).

The second author would like to express his thanks to Professor George Burleson for encouraging him to offer a course in black hole physics (Spring 1999), where the topic of this current investigation was assigned as a problem.
a) Electronic mail: jzund@nmsu.edu

1. See Pankaj S. Joshi, Global Aspects in Gravitation and Cosmology (Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1993) pp 77-82; and for a less mathematical discussion, Jean-Pierre Luminet, Black Holes, (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1992).

2. Remo Ruffini and John A. Wheeler, ‚ÄúRelativistic cosmology and space platforms‚Äù in The Significance of Space Research for Fundamental Physics (European Space Research Organization, Neuilly-sur-Seine, 1971) pp 72-99. This is the technical version of the authors popular exposition ‚ÄúIntroducing the black hole,‚Äù Physics Today, January 1971, 30-41.
3. Jacob D. Bekenstein, ‚ÄúBlack holes and entropy,‚Äù Physical Review D 7, 2333-2346 (1973); and ‚ÄúBlack hole thermodynamics,‚Äù Physics Today, January 1980, 24-31.
4. Roy P. Kerr, ‚ÄúGravitational field of a spinning mass as an example of algebraically special metrics,‚Äù Physical Review Letters 11, 237-238 (1963) and pp 273-318 of reference 5.
5. Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, The Mathematical Theory of Black Holes (Clarendon Press, Oxford 1983) p. 317.
6. Mathcad User‚Äôs Guide: Mathcad 8 Professional (Mathsoft Inc., Cambridge MA, 1998).
7. Stuart L. Shapiro and Saul A. Teukolsky, Black Holes, White Dwarfs, and Neutron Stars (J. Wiley & Sons, New York, 1983) p. 357.
